abstract.t: This specification describes how to declare in a JWT that the presenter of a JWT is a User Agent through which a verifier can be obtained. It further specifies how the reciever can obtain the verifier and confirm that the User Agent is authorized to present the security token. Confirmation in this manner protects these tokens from token export attacks.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This specification describes how to declare in a JWT that the presenter of a JWT is a User Agent through which a verifier can be obtained. It further specifies how the reciever can obtain the verifier and confirm that the User Agent is authorized to present the security token. Confirmation in this manner protects these tokens from token export attacks.

Token confirmation improves security in federated scenarios, and in particular federated scenarios that start at the Identity Provider. In an IdP-initiated Federated Sign-On protocol, an Identity Provider issues an identity token to a User Agent, which sends the identity token to a Relying Party to authenticate itself. Examples of this include OpenID Connect (where the identity token is called "ID Token") and SAML (where the identity token is a SAML assertion).

In such an IdP-initiated flow, the identity token is a bearer token and can be used by any User Agent in posession of the token. Bearer tokens can be exported from the User Agent and replayed in a different User Agent, leaving such flows vulnerable to cross-site request forgery.

This specification allows the issuer of a security token to indicate that a verifier is obtainable via the User Agent to which the token was issued. The Relying Party can confirm this verifier via the User Agent, thereby protecting against token export attacks.

section.title: Cross-Origin Token Confirmation Representation
section.t: This specification defines the new JWT Confirmation Method member cov (cross-origin verifier) and coi (cross-origin verifier ID). The value of the cov member is the verifier that MUST be obtained via the User Agent for the token to be confirmed. The value of the coi member is an identifer for the verifier, and allows identification of a specific verifier in scenarios where multiple verifiers are in use.

section.title: Token Confirmation Protocol
section.t: The goal of cross-origin token confirmation is to confirm that the User Agent presenting the security token is the same User Agent to which the security token was issued. Upon receiving a security token, the Relying Party (called the Token Consumer in this document) obtains the verifier from the Identity Provider (called the Token Provider in this document) via the User Agent using HTML5 Web Messaging. The Token Consumer then confirms that the verifier matches that in the security token. If so, the token was issued by the Token Provider to the presenting User Agent.

The sequence of events is as follows:
The Token Provider issues a security token to the User Agent.
The User Agent presents the security token to the Token Consumer.
The Token Consumer renders a page an invisible iframe from the Token Provider's cross-origin verification iframe endpoint.
The page rendered by the Relying Party posts a message to the Identity Provider's cross-origin verification iframe requesting the verifier.
The Identity Provider's cross-origin verification iframe posts a message to the Relying Party page which contains the verifier.
The Relying Party submits the verifier to its confirmation endpoint.
The Relying Party confirms the verifier, and if confirmed continues processing the operation requested using the security token.
